verses.text: As Jesus was passing by, he saw a man who had been blind from birth.
verses.comment: Jesus initiates the encounter, underscoring divine initiative in salvation. The man's blindness from birth will serve as a sign demonstrating Jesus’ power and the purpose of suffering.

verses.text: His disciples asked him, 'Rabbi, who sinned, this man or his parents, that he was born blind?'
verses.comment: The disciples reflect a common belief that physical suffering is a result of personal or ancestral sin. Jesus corrects this misconception.

verses.text: Jesus answered, 'Neither this man nor his parents sinned, but this happened so that the works of God might be revealed in him.'
verses.comment: Jesus reveals suffering can be a means to display God's glory instead of being a direct result of sin. Note the emphasis on God working through human frailty, prefiguring sacramental ideas where God works through material realities.

verses.text: 'We must do the works of him who sent me while it is day. Night is coming when no one can work.'
verses.comment: The metaphor of day and night references the limited time of Christ's earthly ministry. Jesus aligns his mission with the Father's will, echoing the importance of a shared mission for his followers.

verses.text: 'As long as I am in the world, I am the light of the world.'
verses.comment: Here, Jesus explicitly claims to be 'the light of the world,' a reference to divine identity (see John 8:12). This fulfills messianic prophecies and points to his divine authority.

verses.text: After saying this, he spit on the ground, made mud with the saliva, and smeared the mud on the man's eyes.
verses.comment: Jesus uses physical means—mud and saliva—to convey healing. This act of healing through matter prefigures the principle of God working through physical signs.

verses.text: He told him, 'Go, wash in the pool of Siloam' (which means Sent). So he went, washed, and came back able to see.
verses.comment: Obedience in faith is required for healing. The command to wash recalls symbolic uses of water in purification and healing, hinting at sacramental grace and the power of ritual.

verses.text: His neighbors and those who had seen him before as a beggar were saying, 'Isn’t this the man who used to sit and beg?'
verses.comment: The transformation is so remarkable that people question his identity. This points to the radical nature of God's work in a person’s life.

verses.text: Some said, 'It is he.' Others said, 'No, but he looks like him.' He kept saying, 'I am the one.'
verses.comment: The healed man openly testifies to his identity, paralleling how those touched by Christ bear witness to his power.

verses.text: So they asked him, 'Then how were your eyes opened?'
verses.comment: The crowd seeks an explanation for the miracle, prompting a witness to Christ’s deeds.

verses.text: He answered, 'The man called Jesus made mud, smeared it on my eyes, and said,
verses.comment: He calls Jesus 'the man,' showing that his understanding is still developing. His journey parallels steps of faith and deeper revelation.

verses.text: They asked him, 'Where is he?' He said, 'I don’t know.'
verses.comment: The man does not yet see Jesus physically, paralleling how belief sometimes precedes full knowledge.

verses.text: They brought to the Pharisees the man who had formerly been blind.
verses.comment: The Pharisees are introduced as religious leaders and eventual opponents, paralleling disputes over Christ's authority.

verses.text: Now it was a Sabbath day when Jesus made the mud and opened his eyes.
verses.comment: Healing on the Sabbath challenges narrow interpretations of the Law, showing that the works of God transcend legalistic constraints.

verses.text: So the Pharisees again asked him how he had received his sight. He said to them, 'He put mud on my eyes, I washed, and now I see.'
verses.comment: The account emphasizes the physical actions involved, again highlighting God’s use of material elements in bestowing grace.

verses.text: Some of the Pharisees said, 'This man is not from God, for he does not keep the Sabbath.' But others said, 'How can a man who is a sinner do such signs?' And there was division among them.
verses.comment: A division arises over Jesus' authority—miracles lead some to faith, others to skepticism. Christ’s actions provoke discernment about true spiritual leadership.

verses.text: So they said again to the blind man, 'What do you say about him, since he opened your eyes?' He said, 'He is a prophet.'
verses.comment: The man expresses growing faith, identifying Jesus as a prophet. This acknowledges both his authority and fulfillment of Old Testament expectations.

verses.text: The Jews did not believe that he had been blind and had received his sight, until they called the parents of the man who had received his sight.
verses.comment: The religious leaders challenge the credibility of the miracle, demanding verification. This lack of faith contrasts with simple receptivity.

verses.text: They asked them, 'Is this your son, who you say was born blind? How then does he now see?'
verses.comment: Their investigation focuses on the facts, but misses the spiritual significance of the miracle.

verses.text: His parents answered, 'We know that this is our son and that he was born blind.'
verses.comment: The parents confirm part of the testimony but remain cautious, illustrating fear of repercussions from religious leadership.

verses.text: 'But how he now sees we do not know, nor do we know who opened his eyes. Ask him; he is of age. He will speak for himself.'
verses.comment: The parents distance themselves, perhaps out of fear, leaving responsibility for testimony to the son. This echoes the importance of personal confession of faith.

verses.text: His parents said these things because they feared the Jews, for the Jews had already agreed that if anyone should confess Jesus to be the Messiah, he was to be put out of the synagogue.
verses.comment: Fear of exclusion and loss of communion with God’s people influences their testimony. This highlights the cost of discipleship and public confession.

verses.text: Therefore his parents said, 'He is of age; ask him.'
verses.comment: Deference is again shown to the healed man’s personal testimony, showing the necessity of taking individual responsibility for faith.

verses.text: So for the second time they called the man who had been blind and said to him, 'Give glory to God. We know that this man is a sinner.'
verses.comment: Despite calling him to thanksgiving, the leaders presuppose Jesus is a sinner, revealing their unjust judgment.

verses.text: He answered, 'Whether he is a sinner I do not know. One thing I do know, that though I was blind, now I see.'
verses.comment: The man’s testimony is based on experience, not theological speculation. His honesty models the simplicity of true faith.

verses.text: They said to him, 'What did he do to you? How did he open your eyes?'
verses.comment: The repeated questioning suggests a desire to undermine the miracle, ignoring the reality of the man's healing.

verses.text: He answered them, 'I told you already, and you would not listen. Why do you want to hear it again? Do you also want to become his disciples?'
verses.comment: The healed man grows bold, offering a challenge that exposes the council’s closed hearts. His response shows the transformation brought about by an encounter with Jesus.

verses.text: They mocked him, saying, 'You are his disciple, but we are disciples of Moses.'
verses.comment: The leaders claim spiritual lineage from Moses, rejecting Jesus’ authority. Jesus had already taught, however, that Moses wrote about him (John 5:46).

verses.text: 'We know that God has spoken to Moses, but as for this man, we don’t know where he comes from.'
verses.comment: Questioning Jesus’ origin again implicitly raises the question of his divine mission and fulfillment of prophecy.

verses.text: The man answered, 'Well, this is astonishing! You don’t know where he comes from, and yet he opened my eyes.'
verses.comment: The healed man is surprised that the leaders cannot discern something so evident—only someone sent by God could perform such a sign.

verses.text: 'We know that God does not listen to sinners, but if anyone is devoted to God and does his will, God listens to him.'
verses.comment: The man applies scriptural wisdom—true devotion and obedience to God are necessary for one’s prayers, or works, to be accepted.

verses.text: 'Never since the world began has it been heard that anyone opened the eyes of a man born blind.'
verses.comment: The uniqueness of the miracle points to the Messiah’s arrival, predicted in prophecies about the restoration of sight.

verses.text: 'If this man were not from God, he could do nothing.'
verses.comment: He expresses faith that Jesus’ miraculous works are only possible because God sent him. This highlights the principle of authentic authority validated by divine works.

verses.text: They answered him, 'You were born entirely in sin, and you are teaching us?' And they threw him out.
verses.comment: The leaders fall back on prejudice, expelling him from community instead of accepting his witness. True faith often results in exclusion or persecution from the powers of the world.

verses.text: Jesus heard that they had thrown him out, and when he found him he said, 'Do you believe in the Son of Man?'
verses.comment: Jesus’ title, 'Son of Man,' is a reference to the divine figure in Daniel who has everlasting authority (Dan 7:13–14), again affirming his divine identity.

verses.text: He answered, 'And who is he, sir, that I may believe in him?'
verses.comment: The healed man demonstrates sincere openness to faith, seeking the truth about Jesus’ identity.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'You have both seen him, and he is the one speaking with you.'
verses.comment: Jesus now directly reveals his Messianic identity, a rare and explicit self-disclosure paralleling John 4:26. This shows the fullness of revelation to those with faith.

verses.text: He said, 'Lord, I believe,' and he worshiped him.
verses.comment: The healed man confesses faith in Jesus, addressing him as 'Lord' and worshipping him, a clear sign of recognizing Christ’s divinity.

verses.text: Jesus said, 'For judgment I came into this world, so that those who do not see may see, and those who do see may become blind.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ mission brings discernment—those who are humble and recognize their need receive revelation, while the self-assured become blind. Notice the spiritual dimension of sight and blindness.

verses.text: Some of the Pharisees who were with him heard this, and said to him, 'Are we also blind?'
verses.comment: The Pharisees challenge Jesus’ statement, exposing their spiritual blindness. The narrative invites the reader to self-examination about spiritual receptivity.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, 'If you were blind, you would not have sin; but now that you say,
verses.comment: Jesus teaches that spiritual pride and persistent rejection of revelation leads to guilt. True sight comes from recognizing one’s need for grace.
